III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth received news that put them in an emotional state. The
youth has asthma and began to cough and breathe heavy. The
youth was unconscious for 17 minutes. Staff checked on the
youth's vitals and the youth's oxygen levels were low. There was
no medical treatment provided. When the youth woke, they were
sent back to their room. The youth had arm and chest pain.
Administration felt the youth was faking the incident.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 7/7/25 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported he worked the 2pm-10pm
shift on 6/26/25. Staff 1 reported Youth A had been taken to the
hospital earlier in the day for chest x-rays due to having a bad
cough, but they were still waiting for the results. Staff 1 reported
around 8pm, Youth A had an asthma attack, therefore Staff 1 and
Supervisor were going to give him a nebulizer treatment. Staff 1
reported Youth A received news from Youth B that had a large
emotional effect on him while he was dealing with his asthma
attack. Staff 1 reported Youth A stayed emotionally distraught for
approximately 30 minutes (until 8:30pm). Staff 1 reported Youth A
had halfway gathered himself as his coughing subsided and his
emotions were a little more in check. Staff 1 reported they took
Youth A to the main room to start the nebulizer treatment. Staff 1
reported approximately halfway away from Youth A’s room, Youth
A said he felt light on his feet, so Staff 1 obtained a chair for him to
sit on. Youth A was hunched over in the chair, and then passed
out, and hit the floor face-first. Staff 1 reported he wasn’t able to
catch Youth A as he was falling, but as soon as he fell, Staff 1
helped him roll onto his back onto the floor. Staff 1 reported he
checked Youth A’s breathing, took his pulse, and put him onto his
side in a cradle position when he wasn’t waking up. Staff 1
reported he took a log of Youth A’s pulse. Staff 1 reported at first
Youth A’s pulse was shallow, and somewhere around the 15-
minute mark after passing out, Youth A’s heartbeat became
irregular. Staff 1 reported he asked Supervisor for an ambulance
to be called, and asked how far out they were, but Supervisor kept
skirting the question and nodding his head. Staff 1 reported it
wasn’t clear what Supervisor was doing. Staff 1 reported Youth A
2

woke up approximately 17 minutes after passing out. Staff 1
reported once Youth A was awake, Staff 1 asked for a pulse-ox
machine and Supervisor obtained it for him around the 20-25
minute range after the incident began. Staff 1 reported Youth A’s
pulse-ox was 93 and 88 is considered critical. Staff 1 reported he
took Youth A’s blood pressure as well, which was normal. Staff 1
reported when Youth A initially woke up, he was very confused,
and it took a couple minutes of Staff 1 talking to Youth A before
Youth A acknowledged him. Staff 1 reported Youth A struggled to
count to 10 at first, but was able to after a couple of tries. Staff 1
reported Youth A said he had pain in his chest and arm. Staff 1
reported he told Supervisor Youth A had signs of a serious cardiac
event. Staff 1 reported Youth A drank half a cup of water and sat
there for approximately 30 more minutes, until he seemed okay to
get up. Staff 1 reported Supervisor showed him a series of text
messages showing a decision was made not to call an
ambulance, against Staff 1’s wishes, and Youth A was sent to
bed. Staff 1 reported he does not know who was included in the
group text message conversation. Staff 1 reported Supervisor took
over after that as Staff 1 left since his shift was over at 10pm. Staff
1 reported Youth A never requested to go to the hospital but
asked if anyone called his dad and asked if his dad would meet
him at the hospital. Staff 1 reported he checked on Youth A the
following morning, and Youth A didn’t look great. Staff 1 reported
Youth A said his teeth and mouth hurt, which he received Orajel
for. Staff 1 reported around 11:30am-12pm, Youth A began
looking like himself again. Staff 1 reported around 2pm, Team
Leader 2 talked to him about the situation and told him many
youth have faked things like this and alluded that Youth A was
faking things for attention, and stated they typically use smelling
salts to wake youth up. Staff 1 reported Supervisor never came
over to Youth A with smelling salts or used smelling salts. When
asked about his medical training for the assessments he made,
Staff 1 reported he previously had CPR and First Aid training, and
doctors previously taught him how to take his own pulse, so he
knew how to take Youth A’s.
Youth A was interviewed via phone on 7/7/25 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported on 6/26/25, he received
information his pregnant girlfriend was removed from her
grandmother’s care. Youth A reported he became upset and cried
for approximately 30 minutes. Youth A reported he then left his
room to do a breathing (nebulizer) treatment. Youth A reported to
a staff (couldn’t remember who) and Supervisor he felt
lightheaded and couldn’t walk anymore and they gave him a chair
to sit in. Youth A reported he had begun crying again and then he
3

started zoning out. Youth A reported he felt his eyesight was
turning black, and then he passed out. Youth A reported he didn’t
hear anything after he passed out. Youth A reported he didn’t feel
anyone tapping him or trying to wake him up after he passed out.
Youth A reported after he woke up, staff (couldn’t remember who)
and Supervisor took his pulse and checked his lungs. Youth A
reported at first, he thought he was going to the hospital because
the staff (couldn’t remember who) said he was, but they decided
not to take him to the hospital. Youth A reported he completed his
breathing treatment. Youth A reported he then went to his room,
and staff were watching him. Youth A reported the last time he
passed out was in 6th grade and it was because he smelled fish,
which he is allergic to. Youth A reported how he felt when he
passed out that time is exactly how he felt this time. Youth A
reported he felt he should have gone to the hospital because his
left leg, left arm, and head hurt. Youth A reported he thinks the
pain was probably from him passing out and falling out of the chair
onto the floor. Youth A reported on 6/27/25, his arm still hurt, he
was wheezing, and his chest hurt. Youth A reported he saw a
doctor on Saturday (6/28/25) or Sunday (6/29/25), and then again
on Monday (6/30/25).
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/2/25
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported he
knows Youth A well because Youth A is his sister’s baby’s father,
and the baby is due soon. Youth B reported on 6/26/25, he
received news his sister was taken away from their grandmother’s
care. Youth B reported he was upset and crying after he found
out. Youth B reported he told Youth A the news, and Youth A
began to get upset and began crying as well. Youth B reported he
doesn’t know of anything happening after Youth A received the
news. Youth B reported he has had a few medical issues since
being at the facility and he has seen a doctor. Youth B reported
staff have always taken care of his medications and treatment
without issue.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via phone on 7/2/25
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. CA reported Staff 1 was
terminated on Friday (6/27/25) for insubordination. CA reported
Staff 1 was out of line on many things and frequently argued with
other staff and supervisors. CA reported Staff 1 would frequently
get into other staff’s faces about medical situations and would say
staff needed to do certain things, or question what staff were
doing. CA reported Staff 1 was not assigned or trained to pass
medications, so he shouldn’t have been questioning what other
staff were doing or telling them what they should be doing. CA
4

reported Youth A had an inhaler and nebulizer and had been
under doctor’s care for his cough and breathing. CA reported
Youth A had a chest x-ray on 6/26/25 and the doctor called on
6/27/25 to let them know nothing was wrong and to continue with
the inhaler and nebulizer treatments as needed. CA reported she
was not aware of Youth A reporting chest or arm pain after the
incident.
Team Leader 1 (TL1) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 7/2/25 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. TL1
reported on 6/26/25, Youth A not only received the news about his
pregnant girlfriend in the evening, but earlier in the day he was
resentenced. TL1 reported Youth A had a lot going on which
made him upset. TL1 reported he spoke with Youth A on 6/27/25
in the morning and Youth A reported his stomach hurt because he
was so worried about his girlfriend. Youth A told TL1 nothing
happened the night before, and he was just upset because he
wanted to go home. TL1 reported Youth A told him he didn’t need
any medication or medical care; he just wanted to know where his
girlfriend was and what was going on with her. TL1 reported he
wasn’t present for the situation on 6/26/25, but he read the
incident report and there was nothing concerning noted. TL1
reported Youth A had a follow-up doctor’s appointment on Monday
(6/30/25) and the doctor cleared him, stating everything was fine,
and he no longer needed his prescription for Prednisone.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
7/2/25 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor
reported on 6/26/25, Youth A found learned his girlfriend was
removed from her grandmother’s care. Youth A was crying from
approximately 8pm-8:20pm. Supervisor reported Youth A was
really upset and requested to use his nebulizer, so Supervisor
reported he and Staff 1 were sitting with Youth A while they were
getting it prepped. Supervisor reported they went to complete
observation checks on other youth in their rooms, and when he
returned, Youth A was lying on the floor with Staff 1 next to him.
Supervisor reported Staff 1 told him Youth A fell over and passed
out on the floor. Supervisor reported Youth A wasn’t verbally
responsive, his eyes were closed, but he was breathing.
Supervisor reported Youth A’s oxygen and pulse were within
normal range. Supervisor reported he called on-call and CA to tell
them what was happening. Supervisor reported since Youth A
didn’t respond to his name, he was going to try smelling salts to
see if Youth A would respond to those and wake up. Supervisor
reported he went to get smelling salts, but when he got back,
Youth A was already up. Supervisor reported Youth A was passed
5

out on the floor for approximately 15 minutes before he woke up.
Supervisor reported Youth A stated he was dizzy, but okay.
Supervisor reported Youth A did not complain of any chest, arm,
or any other pain while he was present. Supervisor reported he
provided Youth A with water, and around 9:30pm, Youth A used
the nebulizer. Supervisor reported after Youth A went to bed, he
was on 5-minute observation checks to make sure he was okay.
Supervisor reported he sat with Youth A until 10:15pm, and there
were no concerns or issues. Supervisor reported he left around
12am on 6/27/25. Supervisor reported he put Youth A on the list to
see the doctor on Monday (6/30/25). Supervisor reported when he
spoke with Team Leader 2 and CA, he was instructed Youth A did
not need to go to the hospital, but if the situation changed/became
worse, to call an ambulance. Supervisor reported Staff 1 showed
care and concern towards Youth A during the incident. However,
Supervisor reported Staff 1 was very pushy and immediately
wanted to call 911 and have Youth A taken to the hospital.
Supervisor reported he told Staff 1 what their instructions were,
and Staff 1 continued to be pushy. Supervisor reported he
followed up with Staff 1 after the incident, and Staff 1 disclosed an
incident at a previous job that triggered him to want Youth A to be
seen at the hospital as soon as possible. Supervisor reported he,
CA and Team Leader 2 never insinuated or implied Youth A was
faking the incident or trying to get attention.
Team Leader 2 (TL2) was interviewed via phone on 7/7/25 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. TL2 reported she received a
call from Supervisor on 6/26/25 because she was on call.
Supervisor stated Youth A received upsetting news about his
girlfriend and became upset and emotional. TL2 reported
Supervisor told her he was going to give Youth A his nebulizer
treatment, but then Youth A put his head in his hands and then
laid on the floor. Supervisor told TL2 Youth A was breathing and
had a pulse. TL2 reported their CPR instructor taught them if
someone passes out, but is breathing, then they use smelling
salts, or a sternum rub to see if they respond. TL2 reported she
instructed Supervisor to do the pulse-ox meter to check his status
first, and it came back normal. Supervisor reported she then
advised him to use the smelling salts and then the sternum rub.
TL2 reported Supervisor called her back, and right when he was
about to use the smelling salts, Youth A sat up. TL2 reported it
was apparent from the situation, it was Youth A’s emotional
reaction which caused him to pass out rather than it being
evidence of a medical issue. TL2 reported the following day TL1
reviewed the video, and there were no concerns noted. TL2
reported the doctor saw Youth A and verified he was medically
6

fine. TL2 reported when she talked to Youth A, Youth A was very
emotionally fixated on what was going on with his girlfriend. TL2
reported Youth A repeatedly said he was fine, and said he put his
head in his hands the previous night because he was overly
emotional.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from 6/26/25 was reviewed, and it does not have
audio. Supervisor and Youth A are seen sitting in chairs across
from each other at a table in the main pod area. Staff 1 is standing
and walking around by Youth A. Youth A is hunched over in the
chair. Staff 1 picks up a chair, sets it within 5 feet of Youth A, and
sits down facing Youth A. Supervisor gets up and walks down the
bedroom hallway. At 8:41pm, Youth A falls forward out of the chair
and his knees, face & head hit the floor first. Then his shoulder,
arm and legs hit the floor, so he is laying on his stomach/side.
Staff 1 gets up, stands over Youth A, and rolls him onto his side.
Supervisor comes back and then goes into the office/observation
room while Staff 1 lays Youth A on his back. Staff 1 sits by Youth
A on the floor, and it appears he is monitoring Youth A’s vitals.
Supervisor opens the observation room/office door a couple times
and then closes it again. Staff 1 continues to sit on the floor and
monitor Youth A. Staff 1 then turns Youth A onto his side and
kneels next to him, holding his back/shoulder so he remains on his
side. Staff 1 holds Youth A’s wrist, and it appears he is checking
his pulse. At 8:49pm, Supervisor comes out of the office, reaches
down to check on Youth A, and then enters another room. Staff 1
continues to sit on the floor near Youth A and puts his hand on
Youth A’s wrist every so often. At 8:52pm, Supervisor comes out
of the room and talks to Staff 1. Supervisor then enters another
door into another room. At 8:53pm, Supervisor exits that room and
re-enters the office/observation room. At 8:55pm, Supervisor exits
the office/observation room and then reenters it. At 8:56pm,
Supervisor exits the office/observation room again, and hands a
phone to Staff 1. Staff 1 is looking at the phone while Supervisor
bends over to check on Youth A. Supervisor then goes into
another room. At 8:57pm, Supervisor comes out of the room, goes
by the table, pulls out the chair, and then taps Youth A. Supervisor
stands back up, and then leans over to tap Youth A again. At
8:58pm, Youth A wakes up and Staff 1 helps him sit up. Staff 1
immediately takes off his sweatshirt. Staff 1 sits on the floor next
to Youth A while Supervisor sits in the chair at the table.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Incident Report dated 6/26/25 authored by Supervisor was
consistent with Supervisor’s interview.
7

• Youth A’s admission medical report dated 6/23/25 notes
Youth A had left knee pain after falling on a glass bottle and
hitting his knee cap. He was diagnosed with moderate,
persistent asthma. He already had an inhaler, but he was
also prescribed Prednisone.
• Youth A’s medical report dated 6/30/25 notes his left knee
pain is better. Youth A finished the steroid pack
(Prednisone) he was prescribed for his asthma. His asthma
is better, and he does not have any chest pain, shortness
of breath, wheezing, and only has a very rare cough. Youth
A reported he passed out the evening on 6/26/25. He
described being very worked up, even crying at moments
prior to the incident. Youth A began feeling short of breath
and decided he needed to take treatment via his inhaler.
He subsequently passed out shortly after treatment. Youth
A remembers feeling anxious when waking up, but
physically well. No medical evaluation or call to the on call
number was made. He remained in his room the rest of the
evening and staff made regular checks throughout the
evening. Medical report noted Syncope (aka “loss of
consciousness”) sounded like a vasovagal episode (aka
“sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure leading to
fainting, often in reaction to a stressful trigger”) from acute
anxiety. His history of knowing the events leading up to and
immediately after are not consistent with seizure activity.
There is no history of him complaining about cardiac
symptoms or history of cardiac disease. His cardiac,
neurological, and psych exam were normal today. There is
no evidence of this being an emergency need.
• Unimpeded Access to Care Policy notes when a youth
reports illness or medical problems to staff, the staff shall
complete a medical complaint form for the youth to have
access to the health care providers/physicians. Health care
providers/physicians make routine visits at least twice
weekly (normally Mondays and Thursdays) unless
unforeseen circumstances arise and are available via
phone as needed for all youth.
• Emergency Care Policy states the facility provides for 24-
hour emergency medical care availability including: on-site
emergency first aid and crisis intervention, arrangements
for the emergency evacuation and transfer of youth from
the facility, arrangements for the use of an emergency
8

medical vehicle, arrangements for emergency on-call
assistance from Oaklawn Hospital. In medical emergencies
that pose a risk to the physical well-being of the youth, staff
shall transport the youth to Oaklawn Hospital ER for more
advanced care when indicated by the nature of the
emergency or by the direction of Whole Family Direct Care.
Supervisor shall notify the facility’s director, assistant
director, team leader and On-Call Administrator (if after
hours).
• Supervisor has one disciplinary action in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Supervisor was trained in
CPR/First Aid on 8/12/24 and medical/emergency policies
on 5/6/22 and 9/26/23.
• Staff 1 did not have any formal disciplinary actions in his
employee file. Staff 1 was hired on 6/6/25 and was
terminated on 6/28/25 for insubordination and boundary
crossing because of this incident as well as other
situations. Staff 1 was trained on medical/emergency
policies on 6/6/25. There is no record of Staff 1 having
CPR/First Aid training.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, Youth A was assessed and
monitored by facility staff while he was passed out. Supervisor
communicated with CA and TL2 to receive directions on what
steps to follow, and he followed those steps. Per the facility’s
policy, Supervisor created a medical request for Youth A to be
seen on Monday 6/30/25, and Youth A was seen by the physician.
The medical note dated 6/30/25 confirms Youth A passed out due
to acute anxiety caused by a stressful trigger. The medical note
also states there is no evidence of this being an emergency need.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• Although there is no indication a call to 911 to request an
ambulance or hospital trip was warranted, Youth A’s
medical note dated 6/30/25 states no medical evaluation or
call to on-call was made. Since the facility has access to
24-hour on call physicians/health care providers, they
should be consulted in future situations of this nature or
other medical emergencies, and those consultations should
be documented in the incident report completed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
